Authors:
Mayu Maeda, Jamjan Meeboon, Vasyl P. Heluta, Shu-Yan Liu,
Shurong Tang, Susumu Takamatsu
Title:
Phylogeny and taxonomy of Phyllactinia species (powdery
mildew: Erysiphaceae) occurring on the ash trees (Fraxinus spp.)
Keywords:
Biogeography, Epitype, New species, Phyllactinia
fraxini-longicuspi, Phyllactinia japonica
Abstract:
The genus Fraxinus (Oleaceae), known as ash trees,
currently comprises 43 recognized species that are distributed in
temperate and subtropical regions of the northern hemisphere. Two
Phyllactinia species, P. fraxini and P. fraxinicola, have been known on
Fraxinus spp. so far. In this study, powdery mildews belonging to
Phyllactinia were collected on Fraxinus from different areas of the
world to make molecular and morphological analyses. These specimens are
divided into four distinct molecular phylogenetic groups, which are
distinguishable by their morphology and/or host preference. Two new
species, viz., P. japonica occurring on F. sieboldina and F. lanuginosa
f.Â serrata, and P. fraxini-longicuspi on F. longicuspis, are proposed in
this study. An epitype is designated for P. fraxini. This study
indicates strict host specificity among four Phyllactinia species on
Fraxinus, suggesting that genetic isolation by host specificity played
more important role than geographic segregation in the speciation events
of these Phyllactinia species. Evolutionary timing calculated by
molecular clock analysis suggests that these powdery mildews diverged in
accordance with host phylogeny after divergence of host plants.
